I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  discussions  regarding  the  2005  Interim  Country  Strategy  and  Program, 
agreement  was  reached  between  the  Government  of  the  Philippines  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to proceed with a technical assistance (TA) on strengthening local 
government  finance  and  budgeting.  Follow-up  consultations  were  held  in  December  2004 
between the Government and ADB. Both sides reached an understanding on the TA objectives, 
scope,  terms  of  reference,  implementation  arrangements,  and  cost  estimates.1  ADB 
Management cleared the TA concept in November 2004. The TA framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The 1991 Local Government Code (LGC) was an ambitious attempt to expand the 
political  and  economic  role  of  local  government  units  (LGUs).  A  large  portion  of  national 
government spending responsibilities was devolved at that time, and the portion of national 
government revenues flowing to LGUs through intergovernmental transfers was more than 
doubled to fund that spending. This was seen as a means of bringing government service 
delivery closer to its end users and as a major step to strengthen democracy, by making LGUs 
more autonomous, transparent, and accountable. However, after 13 years the LGC’s compelling 
vision has been only partially realized, and LGUs—with few exceptions—are not yet playing their 
anticipated  role.  Urgent  problems  relating  to  core  LGU  budget  functions  are  the  greatest 
impediment to LGUs’ ability to be effective and accountable. Failure to solve these problems will 
undermine decentralization.  
 
3.  The pressing fiscal problems facing the national government in 2004 have lent even 
greater urgency to the need to strengthen LGU finances. Spending by LGUs in 2003 equaled 
P158.2 billion, or 16.1% of total general government expenditures. National budget transfers to 
LGUs consumed 22.5% of annual national government revenue collections. At the same time 
only 32.6% of LGU expenditures are financed by local revenues, and for a large percentage of 
LGUs  the  share  of  own  revenues  is  considerably  lower.  This  growing  gap  between  LGU 
expenditures and their own revenues is being filled by expanding transfers from the national 
budget through the internal revenue allotment (IRA). Increased dependence on the IRA was an 
inevitable result of the decision in 1991 to devolve new expenditures to LGUs and to finance these 
new expenditures through the IRA. While this dependence was expected to diminish, however, it 
is growing instead: at 67.9% the IRA’s share of total LGU revenues was higher in 2002 than ever 
before. Some LGUs, primarily cities, have been more successful in raising their own revenues. 
For cities as a group in 2002, the share of IRA in total revenues was 47.7%, lower than the 52.5% 
figure in the early post-LGC years. But comparable numbers for municipalities (78.9%) and 
provinces (84.6%) showed greater dependence on the IRA than ever before. This runs directly 
against the Government’s expectation and policy that the Department of Finance (DOF) should 
have the objective of making LGUs less dependent on funding from the national government.”2 
 
4.  Key issues that have impeded LGU financial progress are (i) flaws in the IRA formula, 
leading to a mismatch between the volume of expenditure responsibilities assigned to LGUs and 
of transfers they receive to finance them; (ii) weak LGU ability to access other sources of 
financing, such as bank loans and bonds, due to lack of creditworthiness or credible financial 
information  to  demonstrate  creditworthiness,  often  reflecting  inadequate  institutional  and

2 
technical support; (iii) weak LGU ability to increase own revenues due to legal restrictions, 
inappropriate assignment of tax authority among different levels of local government, poor tax 
administration capacity, and infrequent LGU reassessment of real property values; (iv) problems 
in LGU expenditure management, including poor medium-term budgeting, excessive personal 
service expenditures, and non-transparent processes and procedures; and (v) inefficient and 
non-transparent  LGU  financial  management  practices,  providing  only  limited  local 
accountability. Other problems weaken intergovernmental finance, including the tendency for 
the number of LGUs to grow steadily in order to take advantage of the IRA formula, and 
problems with the national government’s income group classification scheme to rank LGU 
performance and eligibility for participation in programs. 
 
  5.  The Bureau of Local Government Finance (BLGF), attached to DOF, is the national 
government agency that directly addresses these problems. Created by Executive Order 127 
(30 January 1987), BLGF is headed by an executive director and has five main units: (i) Internal 
Administration Office, (ii) Policy Enforcement and Special Projects Group, (iii) Field Operations 
Examination Group, (iv) Management and Technical Staff, and (v) Intelligence and Investigation 
Office. BLGF maintains offices in each region to monitor and provides TA to LGUs in local fiscal 
administration,  specifically  revenue  generation  and  mobilization.  BLGF  also  appoints  local 
treasurers and has some quasi-regulatory and supervisory functions over LGUs. Under the LGC 
the  supervisory  role  of  the  BLGF  has  been  diminished  but  their  developmental  role  and 
functions have come to the fore. LGUs look to BLGF as a provider and developer of programs 
and technical assistance services in local taxation and revenue administration, real property 
taxation and assessment, treasury operations, resource mobilization, and credit financing and 
utilization. 
 
  6.  Growing private sector interest in purchasing LGU debt through municipal bonds is 
creating a need for accurate and timely financial information on LGUs. BLGF is a key provider of 
this  much-needed  information  to  financial  advisors,  bond  underwriters,  and  institutional 
investors.3  BLGF  recently  developed  the  Statement  of  Income  and  Expenditures  (SIE) 
Reporting System and an accompanying set of LGU fiscal and financial performance indicators. 
The performance indicators need to be improved and the system made more useful for LGUs 
and other clients. This has gained importance because municipal bonds will soon be entered 
into the Fixed-Income exchange, which will be the beginning of a secondary market for LGU 
debt. With expanded trade in municipal bonds will come demand for regular credit rating of 
LGUs. This will increase, intensify, and even deepen the need for LGU financial information by 
credit-rating agencies and investors. Similarly, with increased interest in build-operate-transfer 
and joint venture arrangements, potential investors and partners will need financial information 
to evaluate an LGU’s proposals. 
 
7.  As BLGF’s clientele expands to include new stakeholders in LGU development, such as 
municipal bond underwriters and financial advisors, new services need to be developed. With 
the increasing popularity of municipal bonds as a form of financing, financial advisors are now 
approaching LGUs with offers to package projects for bond financing. LGUs require assistance 
in selecting from the many financial advisors and in determining the most appropriate type of 
financing for a project given its nature and the various interest rates. The Bangko Sentral ng 
Pilipinas (BSP) and DOF will increasingly seek accurate and regularly updated information on 
                                                 
3 BLGF is not merely a provider of information but also an integral part of the bond issuance process. Before LGU 
bond flotation, the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the regulatory authority for all bonds, requires BLGF to issue a 
certificate of maximum debt service before issuing a “no-objection” to the bond floatation.

3  
the level and status of LGU debt and related financial information as more and more LGUs enter 
into debt financing and as concerns about default potential are raised. 
 
8.  BLGF, however, spends most of its time administering and managing local treasurers 
(including processing their appointments and validating and ruling on pending administrative 
cases against them) to the detriment of its more developmental functions. It is urgent that 
BLGF’s databases and analytical systems be expanded and enhanced; old services improved 
and branched out into new services; current activities streamlined, harmonized, rationalized, 
and  made  more  efficient;  in-house  expertise  upgraded  in  training,  capacity  building,  and 
technical assistance; and critical legislative agendas pursued.  
 
9.  ADB has extensive experience in providing technical assistance to the Philippines to 
strengthen local governance and local government financing. ADB supported the launch of the 
LGC with a TA for implementing the LGC in the health sector in 1993.4 In 2003, ADB and the 
World Bank conducted a joint study on “decentralized service delivery”,5 which is a valuable 
source of information on a number of issues relevant to this TA. The new TA is designed to 
build on ADB efforts and focus on accelerated implementation of core reforms, by developing 
action  plans  that  will  serve  as  inputs  into  planned  ADB  LGU  finance  operations,  and  by 
strengthening BLGF, a major national government payer in all LGU finance issues. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE  
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The TA will have two components. Component A will provide an analytical overview and 
detailed studies of key issues that will help DOF and BLGF design and implement reform of 
LGU finance and budget processes. These studies will identify factors in the legal, policy, and 
institutional  frameworks  that  impede  LGUs’  ability  to  function  as  autonomous  and  self-
supporting units and propose remedies and concrete action plans to overcome these problems. 
Component B will enhance the capacity of national government agencies, particularly BLGF, to 
provide LGUs with services to improve their finances and create and maintain LGU financial 
performance databases that will strengthen LGU credit markets.  
   
11.  Component A. The TA studies will include the following: (i) legal impediments to LGU 
revenue mobilization; (ii) rationalization of revenue and expenditure assignment between the 
national government and LGUs, and among different levels of LGUs (provinces, municipalities, 
and cities); (iii) issues regarding the LGU classification system by income group; (iv) revision of 
the procedures for creating LGUs; (v) proposals for improving LGU financial management, 
including  internal  audit  capacity  and  greater  transparency  in  procurement  and  financial 
reporting; (vi) review of LGU accounting practices and procedures, including those of local 
government-owned and -controlled corporations (GOCCs); (vii) review of the IRA formula and 
procedures, with recommendations for improvement; (viii) obstacles to LGU access to credit, 
and  recommendations  for  overcoming  them;  (ix)  LGU  tax  administration  problems  and 
proposals for remedies; (x) proper management of the growing role of GOCCs in LGU finance; 
and (xi) methodologies for assessing LGU financial performance. The sequence, interlinkages, 
and detailed content of the studies will be determined in the TA’s first phase, based on a review 
by the intergovernmental fiscal relations expert.

12.  Component B. The TA will enhance the skills, tools, and work programs of BLGF, at its 
main  office  in  Manila  and  regional  offices,  by  conducting  training  and  other  capacity-
development  activities,  designing  information  systems,  and  developing  policy-supporting 
mechanisms  needed  to  enhance  the  bureau’s  services.  Technical  assistance  to  BLGF  is 
expected  to  result  in  more  efficient  and  effective  delivery  of  technical,  policy  advisory, 
management, and administrative assistance to LGUs, and in the creation of a cadre of skilled 
trainers able to provide high-quality assistance to LGUs throughout the country. The TA will also 
enhance LGU access to credit by improving the BLGF database on LGU financial performance, 
allowing potential lenders to better assess creditworthiness. 
 
1.  Methodology and Key Activities  
 
13.  In  the  course  of  both  TA  components,  workshops  and  public  consultations  will  be 
conducted  with  stakeholders.  Along  with  the  TA  studies,  government  issuances  such  as 
executive orders, departmental orders, administrative orders, and memorandum circulars will be 
drafted as the need arises, and as a result of recommendations resulting from studies and 
reports  as  well  as  specific  requests  from  DOF  and  BLGF.  Active  engagement  with  other 
development partners will be maintained throughout to produce outcomes useful to all funding 
agencies working at the LGU level. 
 
14.  Component  A.  The  methodology  of  the  studies  will  include  (i)  desk  studies;  (ii) 
consultations with national government and LGU officials, nongovernment organizations, and 
local  research  organizations;  and  (iii)  consultations  with  private  and  government  financial 
institutions.  
 
15.  Component B. The TA includes expert assistance and other institutional support for 
BLGF to build its capacity and support its administrative development. Activities include (i) 
training  selected  region-based  BLGF  officers  to  serve  as  trainers  for  LGUs  on  resource 
mobilization issues; (ii) helping develop a BLGF manual of operations, to include documentation 
of  the  process  for  computing  and  establishing  LGU  debt  service  capacity  and  borrowing 
capacity; and (iii) helping institutionalize a multisectoral oversight committee to address the 
problems of LGUs vis-à-vis the national agenda (e.g., the fiscal deficit and IRA reduction).  
 
16.   Assistance will also be provided in LGU financial information systems development, and 
in LGU debt monitoring and management. Activities include helping develop (i) an LGU financial 
information database in a useful format that can be easily accessed by potential investors or 
business locators; (ii) a database for financial services providers to LGUs, including financial 
advisors, bond underwriters, bond guarantors, government and private financial institutions, 
funding agency projects, and others; and (iii) an LGU debt management monitoring system to 
provide information to the BSP, DOF, LGUs, financial institutions, LGU bond underwriters, LGU 
bond guarantors, private investors in LGU bonds, and the new Fixed-Income Exchange.  
 
17.  Activities  in  LGU  fiscal  and  administrative  management  will  include  (i)  updating, 
harmonizing, and codifying tax rulings; (ii) helping harmonize the treasurer’s manual with the 
new government accounting system; (iii) helping develop a manual on various modalities of 
traditional and nontraditional ways for LGUs to raise and improve their revenues and finances, 
including documentation and case studies; and (iv) helping review the policy on LGU economic 
enterprises.

5  
  2.  Cost and Financing  
 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,220,000 equivalent, of which $400,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $820,000 equivalent the local currency cost. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance the entire foreign exchange cost as well as $450,000 of the local 
currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA program. The Government 
will finance local currency costs of $370,000 equivalent by providing office space, staff support, 
and other items. The TA cost estimates and budget are in Appendix 2.  
 
3.  Implementation Arrangements  
 
19.  DOF  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  A  steering  committee,  composed  of  the  DOF 
secretary, BLGF executive director, and leadership of the Union of Local Authorities of the 
Philippines or other appropriate LGU organizations, will be established and meet bimonthly. 
BLGF will be the Implementing Agency.  
 
20.  The TA will require approximately 18 person-months of international and 75 person-
months of domestic consultants with expertise in local government finance, debt and credit 
management, public finance economics, fiscal policy, LGU accounting, national government 
accounting,  local  government  taxation,  local  government  administration,  and  public 
administration law. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. The TA will 
be  implemented  over  18  months,  from  April  2005  to  October  2006.  Policy  dialogue  and 
consultation will be carried out with public institutions, the private sector, and other aid agencies. 
Training materials will be prepared as required.  
 
21.  The consultants for component A will be engaged as individuals by ADB in accordance 
with Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  One  consultant,  likely  the  intergovernmental  finance 
expert, will lead the TA, plan and coordinate component-A studies, coordinate cooperation and 
consultations between the two components, and report to ADB on progress in all TA tasks. The 
consultants  for  component  B  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  as  a  firm,  in  accordance  with  its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements acceptable to ADB for engaging 
domestic consultants, using the simplified technical proposals procedures under ADB’s quality- 
and cost-based system. Equipment under component B will be procured in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $850,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the Philippines for the Local Government Finance and Budget Reform 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS  
 
A.  Component A 
 
1.  This component of the technical assistance (TA) will provide analytical inputs for the 
preparation of Department of Finance (DOF) programs to improve local government unit (LGU) 
finance and budgeting and intergovernmental fiscal relations.  
  
2.  Consultants will all be expected to review existing literature and studies on their topics 
and  consult  broadly  with  the  national  government,  local  government,  nongovernment 
organization, and private sector stakeholders. Before work starts, the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) will prepare a project library, including, among others, ADB country performance review 
mission (CPRM) from relevant Philippine projects, to facilitate this review. Wherever possible, 
consultants are to distinguish in their analysis between wealthy, middle-income, and poor LGUs, 
to design recommendations that take into account the issues of the diverse population of LGUs.  
 
3.  Each  consultant  will  prepare  a  brief  inception  report  after  2  weeks  of  work,  and 
preliminary  findings  will  be  presented  in  an  interim  workshop  after  six  weeks  of  work. 
Stakeholder feedback will then be incorporated and recommendations for reform begun, with a 
timetable for their implementation. The timetable will be reviewed in a final workshop, and 
feedback  incorporated  into  the  final  report,  which  will  be  reviewed  by  DOF  and  ADB. 
Consultants  will  give  additional  briefings  on  progress  and  findings  as  requested  by  the 
Government and ADB.  
 
4.  The  TA  will  require  the  services  of  several  international  and  domestic  experts  in 
intergovernmental fiscal relations, and local government finance, tax policy and administration, 
and performance assessment, as well as a legal expert on local government budget operations 
in  the  Philippines.  If  consultants  have  the  necessary  expertise  and  experience,  they  may 
participate in more than one topic; this is preferred. The mix of international and national 
consultants  may  vary,  depending  on  their  qualifications.  Domestic  consultants  with  the 
necessary qualifications can replace international consultants, for example. 
 
5.  The consultants will be as follows: 
 
1.  Intergovernmental Fiscal Relations/TA Coordinator (international, 10 person-
months; domestic, 24 person-months)  
 
6.  The intergovernmental fiscal relations expert will serve as overall TA coordinator. Within 
one month of starting work, the consultant will, in consultation with ADB and DOF, submit a 
proposed plan for this component, covering the sequence, content, and interlinkages among the 
analytical studies. The consultant will also monitor progress in all areas of work, coordinate 
consultations  between  the  two  components,  and  review  work  of  other  experts  working  in 
component A. The consultant will submit brief monthly reports to ADB and DOF, and an overall 
final TA report. 
 
7.  The experts will have experience in intergovernmental fiscal relations, including the 
design of transfer mechanisms; revenue and expenditure assignment between national and 
local government units, and among different levels of LGUs; and issues regarding the number of 
LGUs and procedures for creating and amalgamating LGUs. The experts will analyze issues 
regarding the internal revenue allotment, expenditure and revenue assignments under the Local

Government Code (LGC) and subsequent legislation, practices in creating and amalgamating 
LGUs, and issues regarding the sharing of revenues among LGUs. 
 
2.  Local Government Tax Policy and Administration Experts (international, 3 
person-months; domestic, 6 person-months)  
   
8.  The  experts  will  have  experience  in  a  broad  range  of  issues  in  local  government 
resource mobilization, particularly in tax planning and policy, and in best practices in local 
government  tax  administration.  The  experts  will  analyze  issues  constraining  LGU  tax 
mobilization, including, but not limited to, legal constraints imposed by the LGC and other 
national legislation; weaknesses in local tax policy leading to a failure to tap potential local 
revenues; weaknesses in local tax administration leading to failure to collect a higher level of 
revenues under existing legislation and regulations; specific issues regarding improvement in 
the utilization of the real property tax, specifically ways to more frequently conduct a general 
revision of assessments to update property values; and others. 
 
3.  Local Government Finance Experts (international, 2 person-months; domestic, 
3 person-months)  
 
9.  The experts will have experience in public finance, particularly in local government debt. 
They should have experience in assisting local governments with borrowing strategies and debt 
management,  including  various  debt  instruments;  bank  credits,  bond  flotation,  and  build-
operate-transfer  or  joint  venture  arrangements.  The  experts  will  review  the  state  of  LGU 
borrowing, legal and regulatory obstacles to LGU access to credit, LGU capacity to plan and 
manage their debt strategies, obstacles to greater private financial institution involvement in 
LGU lending, and issues in developing the LGU bond market.  
 
4.  Local Government Performance Assessment Expert (domestic, 4 person-
months)  
 
10.  The consultant will have expertise in a broad range of LGU performance assessment 
methodologies, including best practices in assessing financial performance, service delivery, 
and overall quality of governance. The expert will recommend to the Government and ADB 
ways  to  incorporate  best  practices  into  government  oversight  of  LGUs  and  into  selection 
procedures for LGU participation in projects. 
 
5.  Local  Government  Financial  Analyst/Accountant  (international,  3  person-
months)  
 
11.  The consultant will have expertise in LGU accounting systems and debt management, 
assess systems in place in LGUs, and draft recommendations for harmonization to a standard 
that is (i) consistent with Philippine legal requirements; (ii) adequate for the needs of the 
Government, and for potential lenders and private sector investors; and (iii) viable under the 
state of technical skills and computer systems in LGUs. 
 
6.  Legal Advisor on Reform of Legislation (domestic, 4 person-months)  
 
12.  This advisor must have experience in drafting financial and tax legislation, and will help 
all teams recommend ways to revise laws and regulations.

B.  Component B 
 
1.  This component will provide assistance to the Bureau of Local Government Finance 
(BLGF) and other agencies and institutions mandated to improve LGU finance, by enhancing 
their capability to provide fiscal and financial management training and support services to 
LGUs.  
 
2.  This component will require the services of a team of domestic experts in LGU finance, 
accounting,  taxation,  administration,  and  law;  debt  and  credit  management;  public  finance 
economics; fiscal policy; and national government accounting. The TA will build capacity by 
conducting training activities, designing financial information and analysis/evaluation systems, 
and by developing fiscal and administrative policy-supporting mechanisms to enhance services.  
 
3.  The consultants will organize training and consultation workshops as required.  
 
4.  The team will submit an inception report three weeks after work starts, and an interim 
report three months after work starts. A draft final report will be submitted to DOF and ADB one 
month  before  TA  completion.  There  will  be  two  rounds  of  feedback  and  revision  before 
submission of the final report before TA completion. 
 
 
1.  Local  Government  Finance  Policy  Economist,  Fiscal  Policy  Expert,  and 
Team Leader (domestic, 10 person-months)  
   
5.  The expert must be an economist with experience in local government finance and fiscal 
policy. He or she will do the following: 
 
(i)  Act as overall team leader for this component by managing consultants and their 
outputs. 
(ii)  Coordinate with DOF and other agency management in providing the TA. 
(iii)  Organize  and  manage  consultations  and  workshops  in  support  of  the  technical 
assistance. 
(iv)  Draft progress reports.  
(v)  Help DOF and other agencies advocate legislation in Congress.  
(vi)  Review all consultant outputs.  
(vii)  Review and formulate LGU policy on economic enterprises.  
(viii)  Provide inputs to develop the LGU debt-monitoring system and database.  
(ix)  Formulate and design the financial and economic model for determining LGU fiscal 
capacity.  
(x)  Coordinate with ADB on providing the status of the technical assistance. 
 
6.  The expert should have at least 15 years’ experience in local government finance and 
administration and fiscal policy issues. He or she should have experience in managing a team

coordinating with top officials of the agency on the outputs of the technical assistance and their 
implementation.
